comment_text: Tell me something I didn't know.  Show me the ways.  Show me how the keel was laid and where.  Show me; don't tell me that something was done!

It could be plausibly argued that building over 30 of these ships at $2 million each was a more cost-effective war-fighting move than building a South Dakota class battleship [South Dakota, Alabama, Massachusetts, Indiana] at about $77 million each.

Of course, no single ship was 'built in four days" that was an elapsed time from keel laying to launching a hull. All the sub-assemblies were already fabricated, staged,  and then welded on; factoring in that time it took a lot longer.  Then there was fitting-out time before the ship was ready for service. These were publicity stunts conducted to boost home front morale.
